#summary SVGFig logo
#labels Example

= SVGFig logo =

To make the SVGFig logo, I converted the text "SVGFig" into a path and
increased the number of control points in [http://www.inkscape.org Inkscape],
then transformed the path with a very nonlinear function in SVGFig.

The function is f(x, y) = x + 2 x y^2^, y (1 + 3/2 x + 4 x^2^).  It
bulges on the left and right due to the x^2^ term in the y coordinate
and trails toward the left on the top and bottom due to the y^2^ term
in the x coordinate.

For more examples, see the [ExampleGallery Example Gallery].

{{{
import svgfig

# read in the "SVGFig" text I typed and converted into paths
text = svgfig.load("svgfig_logo_source.svg")

# find my objects (this is all meant to be an interactive process)
print text
the_s = svgfig.pathtoPath(text[1, 1]); the_s.attr = {"stroke":"none", "fill":"black"}
the_v = svgfig.pathtoPath(text[1, 2]); the_v.attr = {"stroke":"none", "fill":"black"}
the_gfig = svgfig.pathtoPath(text[1,3]); the_gfig.attr = {"stroke":"none", "fill":"black"}

# First, get it out of the weirdo units I drew it in, and into something symmetric
symm = svgfig.Fig(the_s, the_v, the_gfig, trans=svgfig.window(240, 320, 235, 275, x=-1, y=-1, width=2, height=2, flipy=False))

# Next, be sure I can draw it normally, taking it from symmetric coordinates into a 200x100 page
svgfig.canvas_outline(svgfig.Fig(symm, trans=svgfig.window(-1, 1, -1, 1, width=200, flipy=False)).SVG(), viewBox="0 0 200 100").inkview()

# This was built up from trial and error.  Lots of tweaking...
curveaxis = svgfig.CurveAxis("0.6*(-0.98+cos(t)), sin(t)", -1.2, 1.2, ticks=21, miniticks=81, labels=False, arrow_start="arrowstart", arrow_end="arrowend", stroke_width="0.5pt")
svgfig.canvas(svgfig.Fig(svgfig.Fig(svgfig.Fig(symm, trans="x-0.1,y"), trans="x + 2*x*y**2, y*(1+1.5*x+4*x**2)"), curveaxis, \
                         trans=svgfig.window(-0.8, 0.7, -1, 1, width=200, flipy=False)).SVG(), viewBox="0 0 200 100").save("svgfig_logo.svg")
}}}
